Apricots.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag until soft and fragrant.

Arugula, bagged and in clamshells.fridge: No matter how fresh the leaves look, follow the expiration date on the package, since bacteria can develop.

Arugula, bunch.tip: If the bunch has roots, wrap it in a damp paper towel before bagging.

Asparagus.tip: Trim the ends before wrapping the spears in a damp paper towel, then in a plastic bag.

Avocados.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag until soft.

Bananas.tip: Ripe bananas can be frozen for baking (the skins will blacken, but the flesh will be fine).

Beets.tip: Separate the leaves from the roots before storing them separately in a plastic bag; the leaves will stay fresh for up to 3 days.

Blackberries.tip: Discard damaged or moldy berries before storing to prevent the spread of mold.
Blackberries.fridge: 2 days (spread in a single layer on a paper towel–lined plate)

Blueberries.tip: Discard damaged or moldy berries before storing to prevent the spread of mold.

Cantaloupe.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag. Before slicing the melon, wash the rind thoroughly to prevent the transmission of bacteria.

Cherries.fridge: 3 days (in an open bag or bowl)

Corn, unshucked.fridge: Best on the first day; 3 days are possible.

Garlic.pantry: 2 months (make sure air can circulate around it)

Ginger.tip: Ginger can be frozen for up to 6 months. It’s not necessary to thaw it before grating.

Grapes.fridge: Best up to 3 days; 1 week is possible (in a bowl or ventilated plastic bag).

Herbs, leafy.tip: Wrap the bunch in a damp paper towel before bagging.
Herbs, leafy.fridge: 3 days (basil, cilantro, chives, tarragon); 5 days (parsley, mint)

Honeydew.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag. Before slicing the melon, wash the rind thoroughly to prevent the transmission of bacteria.

Leeks.tip: Cut off and discard the dark green tops and keep the roots intact.

Lettuce, bagged and in clamshells.fridge: No matter how fresh the leaves look, follow the expiration date on the package, since bacteria can develop.

Mangoes.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag until soft.

Nectarines.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag until soft.

Onions.pantry: 2 months (whole; make sure air can circulate around them)

Peaches.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag until soft and slightly fragrant.

Pears.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag until soft.

Peas, English and in pods.tip: Leave them in the pods until ready to eat.

Plums.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature until soft and the skins develop a silvery, powdery coating.

Potatoes, new and fingerling.pantry: 5 days (make sure air can circulate around them)

Potatoes\u2014red, russet, Yukon gold, a.pantry: 3 weeks (make sure air can circulate around them)

Radishes.tip: Remove the leaves to prolong freshness.
Radishes.fridge: Best up to 3 days; 2 weeks are possible

Raspberries.tip: Discard damaged or moldy berries before storing to prevent the spread of mold.
Raspberries.fridge: 3 days (in a single layer on a paper towel–lined plate)

Rhubarb.tip: Do not eat the leaves; they can be toxic if consumed in large quantities.

Shallots.pantry: 1 month (make sure air can circulate around them)

Spinach, bagged and in clamshells.fridge: No matter how fresh the leaves look, follow the expiration date on the package, since bacteria can develop.

Strawberries.tip: Discard damaged or moldy berries before storing to prevent the spread of mold.

Tomatoes.tip: To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag.

Turnips.tip: Separate the leaves from the roots before storing them separately in a plastic bag; the leaves will stay fresh for up to 3 days.

Watercress, bagged and in clamshells.fridge: No matter how fresh the leaves look, follow the expiration date on the package, since bacteria can develop.

Watermelon.tip: If you can’t refrigerate the melon whole, keep it in the pantry at a cool temperature.
